description.narrative:
Forum Syd inkom i september 2016 med en ansökan till Sida om stöd till programmet Go! Green Ownership 2017-2019. Efter dialog med ambassaden under perioden september - december inkom Forum Syd med kompletterande information rörande programmet den 21 november, samt inlämnade en slutlig budget den 23 december 2016. Insatsen är en fristående fortsättning på tidigare stöd till programmet "Forum Syd - Environment and Climate with human rights and gender perspective", (insatsnummer 51100070). Under föregående avtalsperiod gav Sida ett stöd om 45 000 000 SEK för åren 2014-2016.
Det nya programmet, som bygger på tidigare erfarenheter och programresultat, syftar till att stärka lokala organisationer att engagera fattiga och utsatta befolkningsgrupper, inklusive kvinnor, att hantera grundorsaker till ojämlikhet avseende tillträde till, nyttjande av och kontroll över naturresurser. Marginaliserade grupper ska få stöd i att kräva sina rättigheter, och lokala myndigheter ska få stöd i att genomföra fattigdomsfokuserade och hållbara planer avseende hantering av naturresurser och anpassning till klimatförändringar. En rättighetsbaserad ansats utgör grunden för insatsen. Insatsen uppgår till ett belopp om 49 300 000 SEK för perioden mars 2017 - december 2019. Sida ombeds finansiera hela insatsen.
Programmet och beredningen genomgick en granskning av ambassadens kvalitetssäkringskommitté den 13 februari 2017. Kommentarer och rekommendationer från denna granskning har tagits om hand i beredningen.

In September 2016 Forum Syd submitted a proposal to Sida for support to the programme Go! Green Ownership 2017-2019. After dialogue with the Embassy during the period September - December, Forum Syd submitted complementary information regarding the programme, on 21st November, and a final budget on 23rd December 2016. The contribution is an independent continuation on the previously supported programme ""Forum Syd - Environment and Climate with human rights and gender perspective", (contribution 51100070). During the previous agreement period, Sida gave a support of 45 000 000 SEK for the period 2014-2016.
The new programme, which builds on previous experiences and programme results, aim to strengthen local organisations to engage poor and vulnerable groups, including women, to manage the root causes to inequalities related to access to, use of and control over natural resources. Marginalised groups will have support to demand their rights, and local authorities are provided support to implement poverty focused and sustainable development plans regarding the management of natural resources and adaptation to climate changes. A rights based approach is the basis for the intervention. The programme amounts to an amount of 49,300,000 SEK for the period March 2017-December 2019. Sida is requested to fund the whole programme.
The programme and the assessment was subject to a Quality Assurance committee review on 13th February 2017. Comments and recommendations from this review were incorporated into this assessment.

The overall goal of the programme is to contribute to "Better living condition of community [ies] as they increase access to, control over, and sustainable and equitable use of natural resources by poor and marginalised people, including greater resilience to climate change". Three outcomes have been identified to contribute to the goal: - Increased application of more sustainable fisheries, forestry, and land management practices, and greater resilience to climate change by poor and vulnerable target communities; - Increased participation and influence in decision-making processes in order to increase access and control concerning natural resources and climate change by communities in collaboration with duty-bearers; - Enhanced use of Information/Communication Technology for Development and Communication for Development (ICT4D) measures by partner organisations for increasing equitable and sustainable access to and control over natural resources, and greater resilience to climate change.

tag.narrative: 13.1 - Strengthen resilience and adaptive capacity to climate-related hazards and natural disasters in all countries.
13.1 - Stärka motståndskraften mot och förmågan till anpassning till klimatrelaterade faror och naturkatastrofer i alla länder.
16.7 - Ensure responsive, inclusive, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels.
16.7 - Säkerställa ett lyhört, inkluderande, deltagandebaserat och representativt beslutsfattande på alla nivåer.

5.a - Genomföra reformer för att ge kvinnor lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till finansiella tjänster, arv och naturresurser, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning

5.a - Undertake reforms to give women equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to ownership and control over land and other forms of property, financial services, inheritance and natural resources, in accordance with national laws.

description.narrative:
ForumCiv has implemented the Green Ownership (GO) programme using a human rights based approach in partnership with fifteen local non-governmental organisation targeting 271 communities with a focus on minorities and indigenous populations. The programme has successfully supported communities to gain long-term legal rights over natural resources crucial for their livelihoods, culture and overall wellbeing. The programme has supported communities in their interactions with representatives for both Ministry of Environment (MoE) as well as Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry (MAF), as the communities were engaging in both Community Forestry (CF) and Community Fisheries (CFi) which is under the mandate of MAF and engaging in the conservation activities in Community Protected Areas (CPAs) that are under the auspice of MoE. The programme monitored the economic benefits the communities gained from improved sustainable management and harvest of natural resources. The increase in revenue gain from fisheries and the harvest of Non-Timber Forest Products (NTFPs) could be linked to increase resilience of household benefiting from the programme. Examples of important results are provided in the sections below:
The GO programme had an impact at scale directly befitting more than 188 000 people in the 271 targeted communities that managed an area of almost 400,000 hectares of forests and fishery grounds (flooded forests) - with community fishery being the largest in size with a total of almost 240,00 hectares.
The improved management of fisheries and the harvest of Non-Timber Forest Products (NTFPs) was shown to improve food security among ethnic minorities and in communities receiving support from Save Cambodia's Wildlife. The poverty rate decreased from a baseline value of 17% to 10%. Similarly, Fishery Action Coalition Team (FACT) reported that the annual household income increased from USD 1,920 to USD 2,663 for participant in the community fisheries scheme.
973 families in Human Resource & Rural Economic Development Organisation (HURREDO)s 04 target Community Forest (CF) in Siem Reap could earn an average of $380 from NTFPs. Another 40 families, who are members of Community Refuge Ponds (CRPs), could get around $300 at average from fish products per year.
The sustainable management and conservation of more than 360,000 hectares of forest also contributed to a reduction of green house gases with creating carbon stock of more than an estimated 42 million tons of CO2-equivalent (calculated using REDD methodology).
The assessments showed that almost at third of the the 271 Community Based Organizations (CBOs) applied good sustainable management practices with gender perspectives and conflict sensitivity, which is 8% higher than the expected target.
As results of capacity development by ForumCiv and its partner organizations, 13 communities were able to set up and operate community eco-tourism that has been identified as future source of income benefiting both from a demand from local trourists as well as international tourists. It was noticeably observed that local tourists increasingly visited the eco-tourism sites.
It has been shown that conservation activities have played an important role in shaping positive attitudes of community members toward practices on sustainable natural resources and environment, especially among youths.
In 16 target communities, Village Support Group (VSG) reported observations of incrasing occurence of 10 endangered species. Other eight (8) forest conservation areas of 1222 hectares have increased biodiversity species and flooded forest plants have grown better than in the wetland areas.
In FACTs target areas, direct targeted household in Tonle Sap region increased their average annual income from $1920 to $4360 from fish products. This is attributed to the fishery conservation project carried out by target Community Fisheries (CFi) that resulted in fish production increase within the target areas.
Another significant result of the programme is that CBOs have become platforms for community members to raise their issues, concerns and needs through participatory planning processes and constructive dialogues with the key stakeholders. With capacity development support in institutional strengthening, CBOs performed their roles in more transparent and accountable manner.
The Ministry of Interior (MoI) has announced that it will substantially increase the annual budget allocation from USD 35,000 to USD 75,000. This is a significant results from ForumCiv'c and other partner advocacy for strengthening community based management of natural resources and it is likely to have a significant impact on reducing environmental degradation especially if the promise to further triple the funds in 2023 is kept.
ForumCiv, partner organizations and CBOs have contributed to the amendment process of six laws/policies: law on Environmental & Natural Resources Code, law on Environmental Impact Assessment, Agricultural Land Management law, fishery law, forestry law and law on natural protected areas. The Civil Society Organization (CSO) groups inputs where mainly concerned with the expansion of small-scale fishing rights to fisheries resources for improving livelihood, strengthening roles and responsibilities and the expansion mandates of community fisheries, and the roles of other sub-national stakeholders involvement in fishery management.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
